description: California Sea Lions are playful, social marine mammals with external ear flaps and strong front flippers. They're often seen lounging on docks or rocks and are known for their loud barks and intelligence.

Harbor seals are the most widely distributed species of pinniped and are found in coastal waters of the northern Atlantic and Pacific oceans, along with the North and Baltic seas.  They are brown, silvery white, tan, or gray, and can have spotted patterns. An adult harbor seal can be as large as 6' in length and as heavy as 370 pounds! The layer of blubber under the seal's skin helps to maintain body temperature. They like to stick to familiar resting spots or haul out sites, like Goff Island in Laguna Beach, which are generally rocky areas where they are protected from crashing waves, severe weather conditions or predation.

The Bottlenose Dolphin is easily identifiable by its distinct face shape with its snout and its gray color. The Bottlenose will come close to shore on many occasions and be spottable from the beach. They work together in herds to farm fish together and use echolocation to locate their food.

The common dolphin or the short-beaked common dolphin is a gray dolphin with a lighter gray patch from the eye to the stomach. It is one of the most common dolphins seen. They measure less than 6 feet and live approximately 40 years. Common dolphins are social creatures traveling in large groups.

Gray Whales can grow up to be over 50 feet long and they have gray bodies with small black eyes. Females are typically bigger than males. They are at high risk of getting stuck in fishing nets and when they get stuck they drag themselves along, resulting in fatigue which can lead to death. They are primarily bottom feeders scouring the ocean floor for food and are prayed on by killer whales.
